Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite its successes, the Standard Model of particle physics cannot be the end of the story. There are too many features that the model does not explain, including the origin of dark matter, why neutrino masses are so light, how the matter-antimatter asymmetry arose, and why Charge-Parity-violation only appears when weak forces are concerned. These are the questions that motivate the Rare Event Search Group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). This award provides support for two beyond-Standard-Model searches: the axion search ABRACADABRA, and the neutrinoless double-beta decay (NLDBD) search KamLAND-Zen and related R&D project NuDot. ABRACADABRA will undertake a search for axions, which are one of the particles postulated to form dark matter. A demonstration of neutrinoless double-beta decay would address the questions of why neutrino masses are so light and what produces the matter-anti-matter asymmetry in the universe.

The program will deliver several beneficial aspects to society through its integration of undergraduates into the program. The multidisciplinary aspects of the projects are appealing to students across a range of majors, exposing students to particle and nuclear physics when they might otherwise have missed the opportunity. The NuDOT and ABRACADABRA detectors are being developed in close association with scientists at local companies. This exposes the undergraduates in the group to alternative career paths as well as promoting strong ties between academia and industry

KamLAND-Zen will be the first ton-scale NLDBD experiment. NuDot, which is a potential upgrade path, can open the door to even large scales. On the other hand, ABRACADABRA is leading the way in a new wave of "table top" beyond-Standard-Model experiments. This is a largely unknown experiment, because it is about to bring out first results. ABRACADABRA brings discovery-level particle physics back to the university. The high intellectual merit of the proposed studies is demonstrated by the excellent alignment of the physics questions with the "science drivers" identified by the Particle Physics Program Prioritization Panel (P5). This proposal addresses: 1) the pursuit of the physics associated with neutrino mass; 2) the identification of the new physics of dark matter; and 3) the exploration of the unknown for new particles, interactions and physical principles. This work is similarly well-aligned with the Long Range Plan of the Nuclear Science Advisory Committee (NSAC), which made the call to move quickly on NLDBD experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rare Event Search Group at MIT uses specialized experiments to search for new processes that could answer some of the biggest questions confronting physics: the particle nature of dark matter and the source of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe. The two efforts in the group are KamLAND-Zen 800 and a related R&D effort NuDot which search for neutrinoless double-beta decay, a process if observed would be a clue to the explanation of the matter-antimatter asymmetry and ABRACADABRA and its next iteration DMRadio which search for axion dark matter.

KamLAND-Zen 800 has been taking data for about 2 years.  A world-leading result is imminent, and this result will also inform the understanding of background sources in future experiments. Our group has been active in the development of novel machine learning algorithms for both the identification of background events and the precision tuning of the simulations to improve our machine learning efforts.  NuDot is a roughly 1/1000 prototype of KamLAND-Zen which aims to demonstrate the reconstruction of particle direction, a breakthrough in our ability to reduce backgrounds in this economically scalable technology. NuDot construction is complete and commissioning is underway.

ABRACADABRA performed its first axion dark matter search in 2018 setting the first direct limits on axion dark matter with masses less than 1 micro-eV. An upgrade and second physics run in 2019/2020 proved that we could successfully model the response of the system and produced a second result. We have now joined forces with the DMRadio Pathfinder effort to build a more sensitive cubic-meter scaled experiment to search for axion dark matter. This effort relies heavily on the expertise developed as part of the ABRACADABRA program too design, build and operate an axion dark matter experiment in this region of parameter space.

The Intellectual merit of these two activities is of the highest caliber because they are both pursuing physics topics that have been identified as high priority topics in nuclear and particle physics and address deep questions about the universe. They both use Machine Learning techniques in their analysis and ABRACADABRA is based on state-of-the-art quantum sensing technology, therefore they are in line with two of the highest profile initiatives across all science (Machine Learning/AI and Quantum Information Sciences).

The Broader Impacts address training both a workforce literate in the techniques of Machine Learning/AI and the future quantum work force. The Rare Event search group has a strong track record of training a diverse group of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scientists and this has continued over the time period of this award.
